 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
   75 yo M with chronic respiratory failure with trach, COPD, ESRD, DM 2,
   infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs with
   complicated hospital course who now was transferred again to the [**Hospital Unit Name 44**]
   for hypercarbic respiratory failure now s/p diverting colostomy to
   allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Exact etiology of respiratory
   failure unclear- may include some muscular weakness, PNA and difficulty
   [**1-18**] body habitus .  Suspect some tracheomalacia or tracheal stenosis
   that doesn
t allow air flow when PM valve is in place and make the
   patient unable to tolerate the valve.  O/n [**1-17**] trach positional for
   ventilation but  IP here [**1-19**] could not find prob with trach in multiple
   positions so will leave as is for now. Sputum from [**1-18**] now grew
   pseudomonas and serratia. Currently stable on [**4-20**]. Sputum from [**1-26**]
   growing 3 types GNRs one of which is pseudomonas
   -f/u speciation from [**1-26**] sputum cx
   - Continue ventilator
   - Cipro for 14D course for serratia in sputum. Day 1- [**1-22**].
   - Atrovent nebs and prn albuterol nebs
    # ESRD: On CVVH [**1-22**]- [**1-27**] in order to remove fluid.   HD reinitiated
   [**1-28**] but without fluid removal [**1-18**] persistently low BP.
   - Continue boluses prn for hypotension.  If SBP <70 and not responsive
   to fluids, would choose Levo as pressor of choice.
   - per renal recs, nutrition changed TF [**1-28**] so now getting 50cc/hr not
   70cc/hr
   -HD today
   # Hypotension:  Currently weaned off Levo since [**1-18**]. TSH elevated and
   free T4 low [**1-18**] but likely sick thyroid. Should recheck as outpt.
   Cortisol [**1-18**] nl at 19.
   -continue midodrine, flourinef
   -monitor BPs, mentation
   -consider gentle boluses for hypotension prn
   # S/P Diverting Colostomy: Patient had diverting colostomy on [**1-6**].
   Surgery has signed off. No TTP at site, brown stool and gas in bag.
   Bridge removed by surgery last week and stated no evidence of
   surrounding necrosis or cellulitis. Pt at high risk of ostomy pulling
   back into abd.  On [**1-26**],  surgery stated very poor wound healing with
   some skin loss and would rechk nutrition labs. [**Month (only) 60**] need debridement at
   some point but as there is currently no infection and this would leave
   him with a floating ostomy over fascia, will wait for now. Family has
   been told there are no further surgical options. Ostomy may very well
   retract at some point which would be catastrophic likely spilling feces
   into abd.
   -continue ostomy care
   -f/u surgery reccs
   # Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: s/p  diverting colostomy [**1-6**]. Seems to be
   improving. Plastics debrided extensively [**1-20**] and placed wound vac.
   Debrided again and wound vac replaced [**1-29**].
   - Cont current wound care
   - Pain controlled reasonably well with 100 mcg fentanyl patch ,
   lidocaine patches and morphine PRN
   # Anemia: Hct slightly down at 20  today. Pt has ESRD and is currently
   on Epo treatment, will keep transfusion goal Hct >21%
   - transfuse 1u PRBCs today
   # Hypoglycemia: Since OR procedure pt
s CBGs were noted to be lower.
   Pt
s insulin doses have not changed. TF changed [**1-28**].  This issue seems
   to have resolved at this time.
   # Depression: The patient has been showing decreased interest and signs
   of depression give his current medical situation
   - Cont citalopram 30 mg daily
   - Social work following
   # CAD: TTE [**3-24**] (EF 50% to 55%) with dilated LV cavity. No signs of
   active cardiac ischemia on labs or EKG. Elevated troponin in setting of
   renal failure, and stable from prior checks.
   -Continue statin, off BB until BPs tolerate.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: No active issues. INR today 3.9. While pt
   critically ill and undergoing procedures,  coumadin will be deferred as
   risk of anticoagulation greater than benefits.
   - Off nodal agents until BPs can better tolerate.
     # Osteomyelitis:  No active issues
   -          finished meropenem ([**1-11**] was the completion of 6 week
   course).
     # R BKA/PVD
   - Continue current wound care
   # Plasma Cell Dyscrasia: Known IgA kappa on electrophoresis. Bone
   Marrow with 5-10% plasma cells. ?MGUS. Known retroperitoneal mass s/p
   non-diagnostic FNA and needle core biopsy indicating lymphoid tissue
   with quiescent germinal centers.
   #Prophylaxis: PPI
   #Code: Full
   #Disposition: ICU, case mgmt on board re ultimate placement.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren Pulmonary (Full) - [**2151-1-29**] 10:55 PM 50 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2150-12-29**] 06:34 AM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2150-12-29**] 06:39 AM

   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic respiratory failure, end-stage renal disease, type II diabetes, and a stage IV coccygeal ulcer. He was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently on ventilator support. The patient's sputum cultures have grown Pseudomonas and Serratia, and he is being treated with ciprofloxacin for 14 days. He also has a diverting colostomy and a plasma cell dyscrasia.

The patient's current medical condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is on ventilator support with a respiratory rate of 32 inspirations per minute and a tidal volume of 373 mL. His oxygen saturation is 100%.
* Cardiovascular: His blood pressure is 103/50 mmHg, and his heart rate is 98 beats per minute. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, but it is currently not active.
* Renal: He has end-stage renal disease and is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).
* Endocrine: He has type II diabetes and is being treated with insulin.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a diverting colostomy and a stage IV coccygeal ulcer.
* Skin: He has impaired skin integrity and is at risk of developing pressure ulcers.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's sputum cultures have grown Pseudomonas and Serratia, and he is at risk of developing sepsis.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is at risk of developing further renal failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is compromised, and he is at risk of developing cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Wound complications: The patient's wound care is critical, and he is at risk of developing wound complications such as infection or dehiscence.
* Pressure ulcers: The patient is at risk of developing pressure ulcers due to his impaired skin integrity and prolonged immobility.

Assessment and plan:

* The patient's respiratory status will be closely monitored, and he will continue to receive ventilator support as needed.
* The patient's sputum cultures will be monitored, and he will continue to receive antibiotics as needed.
* The patient's renal function will be closely monitored, and he will continue to receive CVVH as needed.
* The patient's cardiac status will be closely monitored, and he will continue to receive treatment for atrial fibrillation as needed.
* The patient's wound care will be closely monitored, and he will continue to receive treatment for his stage IV coccygeal ulcer as needed.
* The patient's pressure ulcer risk will be closely monitored, and he will receive pressure ulcer prevention measures as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, type 2 diabetes, and an infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer. He was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to obesity hypoventilation and oversedation. The patient is currently being treated for Serratia pneumonia and is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's history of VAPs and HAPs, there is a high risk of VAP developing while on mechanical ventilation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential need for more aggressive respiratory support.
3. Wound infection: The infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer is a high-risk site for further infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be multifactorial and potentially life-threatening, requiring close monitoring and treatment.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's laboratory results show mild electrolyte imbalances, including hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, which could worsen if not addressed.
6. Sepsis: The patient's infected wound and pneumonia increase the risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's ESRD and COPD may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diabetes and COPD may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or pancreatitis.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of their condition and potential medical complications:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, chronic respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior ventilator-associated pneumonias/hospital-acquired pneumonias.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 37.8°C (100.1°F)
* Heart rate: 97 bpm (88-109 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 122/47 mmHg (65-129/61 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute (19-34 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 99%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube, CPAP/PSV mode, and FiO2 of 50%. They are also receiving fluids and medications through IV lines.

Laboratory results:

* Hemoglobin: 5.9 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 15.3-18.4 x10^9/L
* Platelet count: 144-196 x10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.8-2.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 30-41 mg/dL
* Sodium: 105-148 mmol/L
* Potassium: 2.0-4.6 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.9-9.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8-2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.8-3.4 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a high respiratory rate and low oxygen saturation. They may be at risk for further respiratory failure and potential need for intubation.
* Infection: The patient has a history of infected wounds and may be at risk for further infections, particularly with the use of invasive devices such as IV lines and the tracheostomy tube.
* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and they may be at risk for further hemodynamic instability, particularly with the use of vasopressors and other medications.
* Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and they may be at risk for further renal insufficiency and potential need for dialysis.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation may be unstable, and they may be at risk for further cardiovascular instability, particularly with the use of medications and other interventions.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to address their complex medical needs.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic respiratory failure, tracheostomy, COPD, ESRD, DM2, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs.

The patient was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to oversedation/obesity hypoventilation. He is currently being treated for serratia PNA and is receiving ventilatory support.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 122/47 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. His respiratory status is being closely monitored, with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 99%.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL. His white blood cell count is 15.3 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 144 x 10^9/L. His liver function tests are slightly elevated, with an ALT level of 78 mg/dL and an AST level of 2.0 mg/dL. His renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies are negative for any new findings. His microbiology results are pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include the following:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: likely related to OSA/body habitus/weakness. Currently being treated with ventilatory support and antibiotics.
* ESRD: HD today. F/U sodium after HD.
* Hypotension: multifactorial, stable now. Follow.
* Wound care: wound debridement by plastics, wound vac, and close follow-up.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Prolonged ventilation and respiratory failure
* Wound infection and dehiscence
* Sepsis and multi-organ failure
* Hypercarbic respiratory failure leading to cardiac arrest
* Hypotension and shock
* ESRD exacerbation and acute kidney injury
* Metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia and electrolyte imbalances
* Nutritional deficiencies and malnutrition
* Psychosocial complications, such as anxiety, depression, and delirium.

   75 yo M with chronic respiratory failure with trach, COPD, ESRD, DM 2,
   infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs with
   complicated hospital course who now was transferred again to the [**Hospital Unit Name 44**]
   for hypercarbic respiratory failure now s/p diverting colostomy to
   allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Probable multifactorial respiratory
   failure secondary to muscular weakness, PNA and difficulty due to body
   habitus.   O/n [**1-17**] trach positional for ventilation but IP here [**1-19**]
   could not find problem with trach in multiple positions so will leave
   as is for now. Sputum from [**1-18**] now grew pseudomonas and serratia and on
   [**9-25**] no longer serratia but with providencia and pseudomonas.
   - Continue [**4-20**]
   - Cipro for 10 ourse for serratia in sputum on day 9 currently.
   - Atrovent nebs and prn albuterol nebs
     # ESRD: Tolerating HD currently and got yesterday.  BP
s stable.  No

   - Continue boluses prn for hypotension.  If SBP <70 and not responsive
   to fluids, would choose Levo as pressor of choice.
   - per renal recs, nutrition changed TF [**1-28**] so now getting 50cc/hr not
   70cc/hr
   # Hypotension:  Most likely multifactorial with chronic wound infection
   necrosis on ostomy and other issues.  Weaned off Levo since [**1-18**]. TSH
   elevated and free T4 low [**1-18**] but likely sick thyroid.   Cortisol
   checked and normal.
   -continue midodrine, flourinef
   -monitor BPs, mentation
   -consider gentle boluses for hypotension prn
   # S/P Diverting Colostomy: Patient had diverting colostomy on [**1-6**].
   Bridge removed last week and some necrosis around site.  Surgery aware
   and think appearance is not encouraging but few options for
   management.  Family aware there are no further surgical options and
   ostoy may retract into abdomen leading to catastrophic stool
   contamination.
   -continue ostomy care
   -f/u surgery [**Month/Year (2) 8080**]
   # Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: s/p  diverting colostomy [**1-6**]. Seems to be
   improving. Plastics debrided extensively [**1-20**] and placed wound vac.
   Debrided again and wound vac replaced [**1-29**].
   - Cont current wound care
   - Pain controlled reasonably well with 100 mcg fentanyl patch ,
   lidocaine patches and morphine PRN
   # Anemia: Hct back to 23 today.  Will keep transfusion goal Hct >21%
   # Hypoglycemia: Since OR procedure pt
s CBGs were noted to be lower.
   Pt
s insulin doses have not changed. TF changed [**1-28**].  This issue seems
   to have resolved at this time.
   # Depression: The patient has been showing decreased interest and signs
   of depression give his current medical situation
   - Cont citalopram 30 mg daily
   - Social work following
   # CAD: TTE [**3-24**] (EF 50% to 55%) with dilated LV cavity. No signs of
   active cardiac ischemia on labs or EKG. Elevated troponin in setting of
   renal failure, and stable from prior checks.
   -Continue statin, off BB until BPs tolerate.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: No active issues.  INR subtherapeutic but
   holding coumadin  for the moment given multiple other medications,
   potential for more procedures, and generally poor prognosis.
     # Osteomyelitis:  No active issues
   -          finished meropenem ([**1-11**] was the completion of 6 week
   course).
     # R BKA/PVD
   - Continue current wound care
   # Plasma Cell Dyscrasia: Known IgA kappa on electrophoresis. Bone
   Marrow with 5-10% plasma cells. ?MGUS. Known retroperitoneal mass s/p

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with chronic respiratory failure, tracheostomy, COPD, ESRD, DM2, and a history of VAPs/HAPs. He was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently on ventilator support. He has a stage IV coccygeal ulcer, which is being managed with a diverting colostomy and wound care. The patient has a history of anemia, hypoglycemia, depression, CAD, atrial fibrillation, osteomyelitis, and plasma cell dyscrasia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and may worsen if not properly managed. The patient's tracheostomy tube may become dislodged or infected, leading to respiratory distress.
2. Wound infection: The patient's stage IV coccygeal ulcer is at high risk for infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial and may worsen if not properly managed. The patient may require vasopressors or other interventions to maintain blood pressure.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to neurologic damage or other complications.
6. Depression: The patient's depression may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased quality of life and increased risk of suicidal behavior.
7. CAD: The patient's CAD may worsen if not properly managed, leading to myocardial infarction or other complications.
8. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if not properly managed, leading to stroke or other complications.
9. Osteomyelitis: The patient's osteomyelitis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to bone and joint destruction.
10. Plasma cell dyscrasia: The patient's plasma cell dyscrasia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to bone marrow failure or other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's wound infection with antibiotics and wound care.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with vasopressors and other interventions as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and other interventions as necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypoglycemia with insulin and other interventions as necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's depression with antidepressant medication and other interventions as necessary.
7. Continue to manage the patient's CAD with statins and other interventions as necessary.
8. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with anticoagulation therapy and other interventions as necessary.
9. Continue to manage the patient's osteomyelitis with antibiotics and other interventions as necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's plasma cell dyscrasia and adjust therapy as necessary.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: Continue to provide the patient with full nutrition via the Nutren Pulmonary formula.
2. Glycemic control: Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
3. Lines: Continue to monitor the patient's PICC line and dialysis catheter for signs of infection or other complications.
4. Prophylaxis: Continue to provide the patient with DVT prophylaxis with boots and SQ UF heparin, and stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI.
5. VAP: Continue to monitor the patient for signs of VAP and adjust therapy as necessary.

   75 yo M with chronic respiratory failure with trach, COPD, ESRD, DM 2,
   infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs with
   complicated hospital course who now was transferred again to the [**Hospital Unit Name 44**]
   for hypercarbic respiratory failure now s/p diverting colostomy to
   allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Exact etiology of respiratory
   failure unclear- may include some muscular weakness, PNA and difficulty
   [**1-18**] body habitus .  Suspect some tracheomalacia or tracheal stenosis
   that doesn
t allow air flow when PM valve is in place and make the
   patient unable to tolerate the valve.  O/n [**1-17**] trach positional for
   ventilation but  IP here [**1-19**] could not find prob with trach in multiple
   positions so will leave as is for now. Sputum from [**1-18**] now grew
   pseudomonas and serratia. Currently stable on [**4-20**]. Sputum from [**1-26**]
   growing 3 types GNRs one of which is pseudomonas
   -f/u speciation from [**1-26**] sputum cx
   - Continue ventilator
   - Cipro for 14D course for serratia in sputum. Day 1- [**1-22**].
   - Atrovent nebs and prn albuterol nebs
    # ESRD: On CVVH [**1-22**]- [**1-27**] in order to remove fluid.   HD reinitiated
   [**1-28**] but without fluid removal [**1-18**] persistently low BP.
   - Continue boluses prn for hypotension.  If SBP <70 and not responsive
   to fluids, would choose Levo as pressor of choice.
   - per renal recs, nutrition changed TF [**1-28**] so now getting 50cc/hr not
   70cc/hr
   -HD today
   # Hypotension:  Currently weaned off Levo since [**1-18**]. TSH elevated and
   free T4 low [**1-18**] but likely sick thyroid. Should recheck as outpt.
   Cortisol [**1-18**] nl at 19.
   -continue midodrine, flourinef
   -monitor BPs, mentation
   -consider gentle boluses for hypotension prn
   # S/P Diverting Colostomy: Patient had diverting colostomy on [**1-6**].
   Surgery has signed off. No TTP at site, brown stool and gas in bag.
   Bridge removed by surgery last week and stated no evidence of
   surrounding necrosis or cellulitis. Pt at high risk of ostomy pulling
   back into abd.  On [**1-26**],  surgery stated very poor wound healing with
   some skin loss and would rechk nutrition labs. [**Month (only) 60**] need debridement at
   some point but as there is currently no infection and this would leave
   him with a floating ostomy over fascia, will wait for now. Family has
   been told there are no further surgical options. Ostomy may very well
   retract at some point which would be catastrophic likely spilling feces
   into abd.
   -continue ostomy care
   -f/u surgery [**Month (only) 8080**]
   # Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: s/p  diverting colostomy [**1-6**]. Seems to be
   improving. Plastics debrided extensively [**1-20**] and placed wound vac.
   Debrided again and wound vac replaced [**1-29**].
   - Cont current wound care
   - Pain controlled reasonably well with 100 mcg fentanyl patch ,
   lidocaine patches and morphine PRN
   # Anemia: Hct slightly down at 20  today. Pt has ESRD and is currently
   on Epo treatment, will keep transfusion goal Hct >21%
   - transfuse 1u PRBCs today
   # Hypoglycemia: Since OR procedure pt
s CBGs were noted to be lower.
   Pt
s insulin doses have not changed. TF changed [**1-28**].  This issue seems
   to have resolved at this time.
   # Depression: The patient has been showing decreased interest and signs
   of depression give his current medical situation
   - Cont citalopram 30 mg daily
   - Social work following
   # CAD: TTE [**3-24**] (EF 50% to 55%) with dilated LV cavity. No signs of
   active cardiac ischemia on labs or EKG. Elevated troponin in setting of
   renal failure, and stable from prior checks.
   -Continue statin, off BB until BPs tolerate.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: No active issues. INR today 3.9. While pt
   critically ill and undergoing procedures,  coumadin will be deferred as
   risk of anticoagulation greater than benefits.
   - Off nodal agents until BPs can better tolerate.
     # Osteomyelitis:  No active issues
   -          finished meropenem ([**1-11**] was the completion of 6 week
   course).
     # R BKA/PVD
   - Continue current wound care
   # Plasma Cell Dyscrasia: Known IgA kappa on electrophoresis. Bone
   Marrow with 5-10% plasma cells. ?MGUS. Known retroperitoneal mass s/p
   non-diagnostic FNA and needle core biopsy indicating lymphoid tissue
   with quiescent germinal centers.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic respiratory failure, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a stage IV coccygeal ulcer. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) for hypercarbic respiratory failure and has undergone a diverting colostomy to allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer. The patient has a tracheostomy in place and is on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 101 beats per minute, blood pressure of 95/33 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. His respiratory support includes a tracheostomy tube, CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator, and 50% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 15.3 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 24.5%
* Plt: 144 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 0.8 mg/dL
* Glucose: 198 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.5 g/dL
* LDH: 99 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.5 mg/dL
* Mg++: 1.5 mg/dL
* PO4: 1.8 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure
* ESRD
* Type 2 diabetes mellitus
* Stage IV coccygeal ulcer
* Impaired skin integrity
* Altered mental status
* Respiratory failure, chronic
* Hypotension (not shock)
* Osteomyelitis (no active issues)
* Plasma cell dyscrasia (known IgA kappa on electrophoresis)

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
* ESRD: The patient's kidney function may continue to decline, leading to further fluid accumulation and electrolyte imbalances.
* Type 2 diabetes mellitus: The patient's blood glucose levels may fluctuate, leading to hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
* Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: The patient's wound may not heal properly, leading to further complications such as infection or abscess formation.
* Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin may continue to break down, leading to further complications such as infection or pressure ulcers.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status may continue to deteriorate, leading to further complications such as delirium or depression.
* Respiratory failure, chronic: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
* Hypotension (not shock): The patient's blood pressure may continue to be unstable, leading to further complications such as organ failure.
* Osteomyelitis (no active issues): The patient's osteomyelitis may not resolve, leading to further complications such as sepsis or osteopenia.
* Plasma cell dyscrasia (known IgA kappa on electrophoresis): The patient's plasma cell dyscrasia may continue to progress, leading to further complications such as bone marrow failure or lymphoma.

   75 yo M with chronic respiratory failure with trach, COPD, ESRD, DM 2,
   infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs with
   complicated hospital course who now was transferred again to the [**Hospital Unit Name 44**]
   for hypercarbic respiratory failure now s/p diverting colostomy to
   allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Exact etiology of respiratory
   failure unclear- may include some muscular weakness, PNA and difficulty
   [**1-18**] body habitus .  Suspect some tracheomalacia or tracheal stenosis
   that doesn
t allow air flow when PM valve is in place and make the
   patient unable to tolerate the valve.  O/n [**1-17**] trach positional for
   ventilation but  IP here [**1-19**] could not find prob with trach in multiple
   positions so will leave as is for now. Sputum from [**1-18**] now grew
   pseudomonas and serratia. Currently stable on [**4-20**]. Sputum from [**1-26**]
   growing 3 types GNRs one of which is pseudomonas
   -f/u speciation from [**1-26**] sputum cx
   - Continue ventilator
   - Cipro for 14D course for serratia in sputum. Day 1- [**1-22**].
   - Atrovent nebs and prn albuterol nebs
    # ESRD: On CVVH [**1-22**]- [**1-27**] in order to remove fluid.   HD reinitiated
   [**1-28**] but without fluid removal [**1-18**] persistently low BP.
   - Continue boluses prn for hypotension.  If SBP <70 and not responsive
   to fluids, would choose Levo as pressor of choice.
   - per renal recs, nutrition changed TF [**1-28**] so now getting 50cc/hr not
   70cc/hr
   -HD today
   # Hypotension:  Currently weaned off Levo since [**1-18**]. TSH elevated and
   free T4 low [**1-18**] but likely sick thyroid. Should recheck as outpt.
   Cortisol [**1-18**] nl at 19.
   -continue midodrine, flourinef
   -monitor BPs, mentation
   -consider gentle boluses for hypotension prn
   # S/P Diverting Colostomy: Patient had diverting colostomy on [**1-6**].
   Surgery has signed off. No TTP at site, brown stool and gas in bag.
   Bridge removed by surgery last week and stated no evidence of
   surrounding necrosis or cellulitis. Pt at high risk of ostomy pulling
   back into abd.  On [**1-26**],  surgery stated very poor wound healing with
   some skin loss and would rechk nutrition labs. [**Month (only) 60**] need debridement at
   some point but as there is currently no infection and this would leave
   him with a floating ostomy over fascia, will wait for now. Family has
   been told there are no further surgical options. Ostomy may very well
   retract at some point which would be catastrophic likely spilling feces
   into abd.
   -continue ostomy care
   -f/u surgery [**Month (only) 8080**]
   # Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: s/p  diverting colostomy [**1-6**]. Seems to be
   improving. Plastics debrided extensively [**1-20**] and placed wound vac.
   Debrided again and wound vac replaced [**1-29**].
   - Cont current wound care
   - Pain controlled reasonably well with 100 mcg fentanyl patch ,
   lidocaine patches and morphine PRN
   # Anemia: Hct slightly down at 20  today. Pt has ESRD and is currently
   on Epo treatment, will keep transfusion goal Hct >21%
   - transfuse 1u PRBCs today
   # Hypoglycemia: Since OR procedure pt
s CBGs were noted to be lower.
   Pt
s insulin doses have not changed. TF changed [**1-28**].  This issue seems
   to have resolved at this time.
   # Depression: The patient has been showing decreased interest and signs
   of depression give his current medical situation
   - Cont citalopram 30 mg daily
   - Social work following
   # CAD: TTE [**3-24**] (EF 50% to 55%) with dilated LV cavity. No signs of
   active cardiac ischemia on labs or EKG. Elevated troponin in setting of
   renal failure, and stable from prior checks.
   -Continue statin, off BB until BPs tolerate.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: No active issues. INR today 3.9. While pt

   risk of anticoagulation greater than benefits.
   - Off nodal agents until BPs can better tolerate.

   - Continue current wound care
   # Plasma Cell Dyscrasia: Known IgA kappa on electrophoresis. Bone

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with chronic respiratory failure, ESRD, DM2, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs. He was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently on ventilator support. He has a tracheostomy and is experiencing respiratory failure, which may be due to tracheomalacia or tracheal stenosis. He has a diverting colostomy to allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer and is at high risk of ostomy pulling back into his abdomen. He has a history of anemia, hypoglycemia, depression, CAD, atrial fibrillation, and osteomyelitis. He is currently being treated with various medications, including Cipro for serratia in his sputum, and is undergoing dialysis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further decline in his respiratory status.
2. Tracheomalacia or tracheal stenosis: The patient's tracheostomy may be compromised by tracheomalacia or tracheal stenosis, which could lead to further respiratory compromise.
3. Ostomy complications: The patient's diverting colostomy is at high risk of pulling back into his abdomen, which could lead to serious complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further decline in his hematocrit.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemia is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further episodes of hypoglycemia.
6. Depression: The patient's depression is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further decline in his mental status.
7. CAD: The patient's CAD is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further cardiac complications.
8. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further cardiac complications.
9. Osteomyelitis: The patient's osteomyelitis is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further bone and joint complications.
10. Plasma cell dyscrasia: The patient's plasma cell dyscrasia is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further bone marrow and lymphoid tissue complications.

ICU Care:

1. Ventilator support: The patient will continue to receive ventilator support to manage his respiratory failure.
2. Tracheostomy care: The patient's tracheostomy will continue to be cared for to prevent complications.
3. Ostomy care: The patient's diverting colostomy will continue to be cared for to prevent complications.
4. Dialysis: The patient will continue to receive dialysis to manage his ESRD.
5. Medication management: The patient's medications will continue to be managed to prevent complications and improve his condition.
6. Nutrition: The patient will continue to receive nutrition support to manage his anemia and hypoglycemia.
7. Wound care: The patient's wounds will continue to be cared for to prevent complications.
8. Pain management: The patient's pain will continue to be managed to prevent complications.
9. Infection control: The patient will continue to receive infection control measures to prevent further infections.
10. Family support: The patient's family will continue to receive support to manage their loved one's condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with chronic respiratory failure, COPD, ESRD, DM2, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs. He was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently being treated for Serratia PNA. He is on ventilator support and is receiving Ciprofloxacin. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 94/42 mmHg. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving oxygen therapy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory acidosis and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's infected coccygeal ulcer and Serratia PNA may lead to sepsis, which can cause organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to decreased perfusion of vital organs and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Kidney damage: The patient's ESRD and potential sepsis may lead to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's Serratia PNA may worsen, leading to pneumonia and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Wound infection: The patient's infected coccygeal ulcer may worsen, leading to wound infection and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's chronic respiratory failure, COPD, and potential sepsis may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrest or myocardial infarction.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's chronic respiratory failure, COPD, and potential sepsis may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal functions to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, chronic respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, and a history of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). He is currently being treated for serratia pneumonia and has a tracheostomy in place.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3°C (99.1°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (normal range: 93-108 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 94/42 mmHg (normal range: 92-121/48 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 31 breaths per minute (normal range: 21-31 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Diminished breath sounds in the chest
* Absent right radial pulse and left dorsal pedal pulse
* Soft, non-tender abdomen with bowel sounds present
* Neurological examination is incomplete due to the patient's critical condition

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 15.3-18.4 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 20.5-24.5%
* Platelet count: 144-196 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.8-2.0 mg/dL
* Blood glucose: 78-198 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.5 g/dL
* LDH: 99 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.5 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 1.8 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show no new findings.

The patient's current medical complications include:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to oversedation, obesity hypoventilation, and chronic respiratory failure
* ESRD on hemodialysis
* Hypotension, which is multifactorial and stable at present
* Infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, which is being treated with a diverting colostomy to aid in wound healing
* Serratia pneumonia, which is being treated with antibiotics

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing treatment for serratia pneumonia
* Finishing the course of Ciprofloxacin
* Providing prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer
* Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and treating if decompensates
* Following the patient's ESRD and hemodialysis schedule
* Monitoring the patient's blood glucose levels and treating if necessary
* Providing nutritional support with Nutren Pulmonary (Full) at 50 mL/hour

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of hypercarbic respiratory failure, leading to respiratory arrest or failure
* Development of acute kidney injury or worsening of ESRD
* Sepsis or septic shock due to the infected coccygeal ulcer or pneumonia
* DVT or pulmonary embolism due to immobility and risk factors
* Worsening of hypotension, leading to shock or organ dysfunction
* Development of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to stress ulcer or antibiotic use
* Development of antibiotic-resistant infections due to prolonged antibiotic use.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with COPD, chronic respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior ventilator-associated pneumonias (VAPs) and hospital-acquired pneumonias (HAPs). The patient was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to oversedation, obesity hypoventilation, and sleep apnea.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7°C (99.9°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (93-108 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 94/42 mmHg (92/20-121/48 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 31 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: stable

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* White blood cell count: 15.3-18.4 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 20.5-24.5%
* Platelet count: 144-196 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.8-2.0 mg/dL
* Glucose: 78-198 mg/dL
* Other laboratory results: PT/PTT/INR, ALT/AST, Alk Phos/T Bili, Differential-Neuts, Lactic Acid, Albumin, LDH, Ca++, Mg++, and PO4 are within normal limits or slightly elevated.

The patient's imaging results are:

* No new imaging studies were performed.

The patient's microbiology results show:

* Sputum culture positive for Pseudomonas and Providencia stuartii.

The patient's assessment and plan are:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: likely related to oversedation, obesity hypoventilation, and sleep apnea.
* ESRD: on hemodialysis.
* Hypotension: multifactorial, stable now.
* Finish Cipro course.
* Continue PS/TC as tolerated.
* Follow respiratory status and treat if decompensates.
* All other issues per resident note.

The patient's ICU care includes:

* Nutrition: Nutren Pulmonary (Full) at 50 mL/hour.
* Glycemic control: lines and monitoring.
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
* Need for restraints reviewed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: due to hypercarbic respiratory failure, oversedation, obesity hypoventilation, and sleep apnea.
* Infection: due to Pseudomonas and Providencia stuartii in the sputum culture.
* Hypotension: multifactorial, stable now, but may decompensate.
* Kidney injury: due to ESRD and potential nephrotoxicity from antibiotics.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: due to stress ulcer prophylaxis.
* Deep vein thrombosis: due to immobility and lack of prophylaxis.
* Pneumonia: due to colonization of the respiratory tract.
* Sepsis: due to infection and potential bacteremia.
* Cardiovascular instability: due to atrial fibrillation and potential cardiac decompensation.

 HYPOGLYCEMIA

 RENAL FAILURE, END STAGE (END STAGE RENAL DISEASE, ESRD)
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II

   75 yo M with chronic respiratory failure with trach, COPD, ESRD, DM 2,
   infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs with
   complicated hospital course who now was transferred again to the [**Hospital Unit Name 44**]
   for hypercarbic respiratory failure now s/p diverting colostomy to
   allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Probable multifactorial respiratory
   failure secondary to muscular weakness, PNA and difficulty due to body
   habitus.   O/n [**1-17**] trach positional for ventilation but IP here [**1-19**]
   could not find problem with trach in multiple positions so will leave
   as is for now. Sputum from [**1-18**] now grew pseudomonas and serratia and on
   [**9-25**] no longer serratia but with providencia and pseudomonas.
   Thought to be colonized and not active infection although sputum is
   green with low- grade fever. WBC flat.
   - Continue [**4-20**]
   - Cipro for 14D course started [**1-22**].
   - Atrovent nebs and prn albuterol nebs
     # ESRD: Tolerating HD currently and got Sat [**1-30**].  BP
s stable.
   -HD planned today
   - Continue boluses prn for hypotension.  If SBP <70 and not responsive
   to fluids, would choose Levo as pressor of choice.
   - per renal recs, nutrition changed TF [**1-28**] so now getting 50cc/hr not
   70cc/hr
   # Hypotension:  Most likely multifactorial with chronic wound
   infection, retracting ostomy and other issues.  Weaned off Levo since
   [**1-18**]. TSH elevated and free T4 low [**1-18**] but likely sick thyroid.
   Cortisol checked and normal.
   -continue midodrine, flourinef
   -monitor BPs, mentation
   -consider gentle boluses for hypotension prn
   # S/P Diverting Colostomy: Patient had diverting colostomy on [**1-6**].
   Bridge removed during 1^st week of [**Month (only) 1088**] and some necrosis around
   site.  Surgery aware and think appearance is not encouraging but few
   options for management.  Family aware there are no further surgical
   options and ostomy may retract into abdomen leading to catastrophic
   stool contamination.
   -continue ostomy care
   -f/u surgery reccs
   # Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: s/p  diverting colostomy [**1-6**]. Seems to be
   improving. Plastics debrided extensively [**1-20**] and placed wound vac.
   Debrided again and wound vac replaced [**1-29**].
   - Cont current wound care
   - Pain controlled reasonably well with 100 mcg fentanyl patch ,
   lidocaine patches and morphine PRN
   -Change wound vac again today
   # Anemia: Hct back to 23 today.  Will keep transfusion goal Hct >21%
   # Hypoglycemia: Since OR procedure pt
s CBGs were noted to be lower.
   Pt
s insulin doses have not changed. TF changed [**1-28**].  This issue seems
   to have resolved at this time.
   # Depression: The patient has been showing decreased interest and signs
   of depression given his current medical situation
   - Cont citalopram 30 mg daily
   - Social work following
   # CAD: TTE [**3-24**] (EF 50% to 55%) with dilated LV cavity. No signs of
   active cardiac ischemia on labs or EKG. Elevated troponin in setting of
   renal failure, and stable from prior checks.
   -Continue statin, off BB until BPs tolerate.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: No active issues.  INR subtherapeutic but
   holding coumadin  for the moment given multiple other medications,
   potential for more procedures, and generally poor prognosis.
     # Osteomyelitis:  No active issues
   -          finished meropenem ([**1-11**] was the completion of 6 week
   course).
     # R BKA/PVD
   - Continue current wound care
   # Plasma Cell Dyscrasia: Known IgA kappa on electrophoresis. Bone
   Marrow with 5-10% plasma cells. ?MGUS. Known retroperitoneal mass s/p
   non-diagnostic FNA and needle core biopsy indicating lymphoid tissue
   with quiescent germinal centers.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic respiratory failure, end-stage renal disease, diabetes mellitus type II, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior ventilator-associated pneumonias and hospital-acquired pneumonias.

The patient's current condition is complicated by hypercarbic respiratory failure, which is likely multifactorial and secondary to muscular weakness, pneumonia, and difficulty due to his body habitus. The patient's tracheostomy tube is in place, and he is receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 15.8 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 6.6 g/dL, platelet count of 163 x 10^9/L, and creatinine of 1.4 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's medications include lactulose for constipation, Ciprofloxacin for 14 days, atrovent nebs, and prn albuterol nebs for respiratory support. He is also receiving midodrine and fludrocortisone for hypotension.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is a major concern, and he may require further interventions, such as non-invasive ventilation or invasive mechanical ventilation.
2. Wound infection: The patient's infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer is a significant risk factor for sepsis and organ failure. He requires ongoing wound care and close monitoring for signs of infection.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial and may be related to his chronic wound infection, retracting ostomy, and other underlying medical conditions.
4. Renal failure: The patient's end-stage renal disease is a significant risk factor for morbidity and mortality. He requires ongoing dialysis and close monitoring of his electrolyte levels.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to his chronic kidney disease and requires ongoing transfusion support.
6. Depression: The patient's depression is a significant concern, and he requires ongoing psychological support and management.
7. Cardiovascular disease: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and dilated cardiomyopathy puts him at risk for cardiac complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications and requires ongoing close monitoring and management.

   75 yo M with chronic respiratory failure with trach, COPD, ESRD, DM 2,
   infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs with
   complicated hospital course who now was transferred again to the [**Hospital Unit Name 44**]
   for hypercarbic respiratory failure now s/p diverting colostomy to
   allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Probable multifactorial respiratory
   failure secondary to muscular weakness, PNA and difficulty due to body
   habitus.   O/n [**1-17**] trach positional for ventilation but IP here [**1-19**]
   could not find problem with trach in multiple positions so will leave
   as is for now. Sputum from [**1-18**] now grew pseudomonas and serratia and on
   [**9-25**] no longer serratia but with providencia and pseudomonas.
   - Continue [**4-20**]
   - Cipro for 10 ourse for serratia in sputum on day 9 currently.
   - Atrovent nebs and prn albuterol nebs
     # ESRD: Tolerating HD currently and got yesterday.  BP
s stable.  No
   immediate HD needs today.
   - Continue boluses prn for hypotension.  If SBP <70 and not responsive
   to fluids, would choose Levo as pressor of choice.
   - per renal recs, nutrition changed TF [**1-28**] so now getting 50cc/hr not
   70cc/hr
   # Hypotension:  Most likely multifactorial with chronic wound infection
   necrosis on ostomy and other issues.  Weaned off Levo since [**1-18**]. TSH
   elevated and free T4 low [**1-18**] but likely sick thyroid.   Cortisol
   checked and normal.
   -continue midodrine, flourinef
   -monitor BPs, mentation
   -consider gentle boluses for hypotension prn
   # S/P Diverting Colostomy: Patient had diverting colostomy on [**1-6**].
   Bridge removed last week and some necrosis around site.  Surgery aware
   and think appearance is not encouraging but few options for
   management.  Family aware there are no further surgical options and
   ostoy may retract into abdomen leading to catastrophic stool
   contamination.
   -continue ostomy care
   -f/u surgery reccs
   # Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: s/p  diverting colostomy [**1-6**]. Seems to be
   improving. Plastics debrided extensively [**1-20**] and placed wound vac.
   Debrided again and wound vac replaced [**1-29**].
   - Cont current wound care
   - Pain controlled reasonably well with 100 mcg fentanyl patch ,
   lidocaine patches and morphine PRN
   # Anemia: Hct back to 23 today.  Will keep transfusion goal Hct >21%
   # Hypoglycemia: Since OR procedure pt
s CBGs were noted to be lower.
   Pt
s insulin doses have not changed. TF changed [**1-28**].  This issue seems
   to have resolved at this time.
   # Depression: The patient has been showing decreased interest and signs
   of depression give his current medical situation
   - Cont citalopram 30 mg daily
   - Social work following
   # CAD: TTE [**3-24**] (EF 50% to 55%) with dilated LV cavity. No signs of
   active cardiac ischemia on labs or EKG. Elevated troponin in setting of
   renal failure, and stable from prior checks.
   -Continue statin, off BB until BPs tolerate.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: No active issues.  INR subtherapeutic but
   holding coumadin  for the moment given multiple other medications,
   potential for more procedures, and generally poor prognosis.
     # Osteomyelitis:  No active issues
   -          finished meropenem ([**1-11**] was the completion of 6 week
   course).
     # R BKA/PVD
   - Continue current wound care
   # Plasma Cell Dyscrasia: Known IgA kappa on electrophoresis. Bone
   Marrow with 5-10% plasma cells. ?MGUS. Known retroperitoneal mass s/p
   non-diagnostic FNA and needle core biopsy indicating lymphoid tissue
   with quiescent germinal centers.
   #Prophylaxis: PPI, heparin SC

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure, and the note mentions hypercarbic respiratory failure. This can lead to further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, and increased work of breathing.
2. Renal failure: The patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is on hemodialysis. The note mentions that the patient is tolerating dialysis, but there is a risk of further kidney damage or dialysis non-tolerance.
3. Hypotension: The patient has a history of hypotension and is currently being managed with midodrine and fludrocortisone. However, there is a risk of further hypotension episodes, especially with changes in blood pressure or volume status.
4. Wound infection: The patient has a stage IV coccygeal ulcer that is not healing, and there is a risk of further infection or sepsis.
5. Osteomyelitis: Although the note mentions that there are no active issues with osteomyelitis, the patient has a history of osteomyelitis, and there is a risk of recurrence.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and the note mentions that the INR is subtherapeutic. This can increase the risk of stroke or thromboembolism.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has diabetes mellitus type 2, and the note mentions that the patient's insulin doses have not changed. However, there is a risk of hyperglycemia, especially with changes in nutrition or medication.
8. Depression: The patient is showing signs of depression, and there is a risk of further depression or worsening mental status.
9. Anemia: The patient has anemia, and the note mentions that the Hct is back to 23. There is a risk of further anemia or bleeding complications.

In terms of potential medical complications, the patient's medical history and current condition suggest the following:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and hypercarbic respiratory failure put them at risk for further respiratory complications.
2. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and current dialysis status put them at risk for further kidney damage or dialysis non-tolerance.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and CAD put them at risk for further cardiovascular complications, such as stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiac arrest.
4. Infection: The patient's stage IV coccygeal ulcer and history of osteomyelitis put them at risk for further infection or sepsis.
5. Nutritional complications: The patient's malnutrition and anemia put them at risk for further nutritional complications, such as malnutrition-related infections or decreased wound healing.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition and current status put them at risk for a range of medical complications. Close monitoring and management of their condition are necessary to prevent or mitigate these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic respiratory failure, end-stage renal disease, diabetes mellitus type 2, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior ventilator-associated pneumonias and hospital-acquired pneumonias. He was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show a mixed picture, with elevated WBC count, decreased Hct, and abnormal liver function tests. He is also experiencing hypoglycemia, hypotension, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure is likely to worsen due to his underlying conditions, such as COPD and muscular weakness.
2. Sepsis: The patient's infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer and history of VAPs/HAPs increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Renal failure: The patient's end-stage renal disease may worsen due to his chronic kidney disease and potential kidney damage from his underlying conditions.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and CAD increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
5. Wound complications: The patient's infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer and history of VAPs/HAPs increase his risk of developing wound complications, such as osteomyelitis and sepsis.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemia may worsen due to his underlying conditions, such as diabetes mellitus type 2 and chronic kidney disease.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen due to his underlying conditions, such as chronic kidney disease and heart failure.
8. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may worsen due to his underlying conditions, such as chronic kidney disease and hypoglycemia.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires a multidisciplinary approach to manage his various medical complications. The patient's treatment plan should include:

1. Mechanical ventilation: The patient should continue to receive mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory function.
2. Antibiotics: The patient should receive antibiotics to treat his infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer and pseudomonas in his sputum.
3. Renal replacement therapy: The patient should receive renal replacement therapy to manage his end-stage renal disease.
4. Cardiac medications: The patient should receive cardiac medications to manage his atrial fibrillation and CAD.
5. Wound care: The patient should receive wound care to manage his infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer and prevent wound complications.
6. Glycemic control: The patient should receive glycemic control measures to manage his hypoglycemia.
7. Hypotension management: The patient should receive hypotension management measures to prevent and treat his hypotension.
8. Altered mental status management: The patient should receive altered mental status management measures to prevent and treat his altered mental status.

The patient's family should be educated on his condition and treatment plan to ensure that they are aware of his medical complications and can provide appropriate support.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, chronic respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, and multiple prior ventilator-associated pneumonias (VAPs) and hospital-acquired pneumonias (HAPs).

The patient is currently being treated for serratia pneumonia and is receiving antibiotics, including ceftazidime for 10 days. He is also being treated for hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to obesity hypoventilation syndrome, and is receiving non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) with a tracheostomy tube.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, blood pressure of 85/38 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His hemodynamic monitoring shows a cardiac index of 2.2 L/min, and his fluid balance is stable, with a total fluid input of 2,197 mL and a total fluid output of 843 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, as well as decreased hemoglobin and albumin levels. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating kidney dysfunction.

The patient's imaging studies show no new findings, and his microbiology results show a sputum culture positive for Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: likely related to obesity hypoventilation syndrome
* ESRD: on hemodialysis
* Hypotension: multifactorial, stable now, follow
* Serratia pneumonia: being treated with antibiotics
* VAP: being treated with NIPPV and antibiotics

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: due to hypercarbic respiratory failure or VAP
* Sepsis: due to serratia pneumonia
* Kidney dysfunction: due to ESRD
* Hypotension: due to multifactorial causes
* Pneumonia: due to serratia pneumonia
* Ventilator-associated complications: such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or ventilator-associated lung injury (VALI)
* Cardiovascular complications: such as atrial fibrillation or heart failure
* Neurological complications: such as sepsis-induced encephalopathy or respiratory failure-induced brain injury

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic respiratory failure, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, and a history of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). He was transferred to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to oversedation, obesity hypoventilation, and possibly obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) or body habitus/weakness. He is currently being treated for Serratia pneumonia and is on a 10-day course of Ceftaz.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.9°C (100.2°F)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 85/38 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Blood glucose: 147 mg/dL

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 218 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. He is also receiving intravenous fluids, including Heparin sodium and Lansoprazole (Prevacid), and is on a continuous infusion of Nutren Pulmonary (Full) at 50 mL/hour.

Potential medical complications:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to respiratory acidosis, decreased lung compliance, and increased risk of respiratory failure.
2. Serratia pneumonia: The patient's Serratia pneumonia may progress if not adequately treated, leading to worsening respiratory failure, sepsis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. ESRD: The patient's ESRD may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased kidney function, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of complications.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased organ perfusion, increased risk of organ failure, and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. VAP/HAP: The patient's history of VAP/HAP may increase his risk of developing further respiratory infections, sepsis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. OSA: The patient's OSA may worsen if not properly managed, leading to increased risk of respiratory failure, daytime sleepiness, and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Obesity hypoventilation: The patient's obesity hypoventilation may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased lung function, increased risk of respiratory failure, and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, respiratory status, and laboratory results to ensure early detection and management of potential complications.
2. Optimize the patient's mechanical ventilation settings to improve lung function and prevent further respiratory complications.
3. Continue to treat the patient's Serratia pneumonia with antibiotics and monitor for signs of progression or complications.
4. Monitor the patient's ESRD and adjust his hemodialysis schedule as needed to prevent complications.
5. Manage the patient's hypotension with fluids and vasopressors as needed to maintain adequate blood pressure and organ perfusion.
6. Consider referring the patient to a sleep specialist for evaluation and management of OSA.
7. Consider referring the patient to a pulmonologist for evaluation and management of obesity hypoventilation.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

Patient Summary:

* Age: 76 years old
* Underlying conditions: COPD, chronic respiratory failure, ESRD on HD, infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs
* Current condition: Critically ill with hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to oversedation/obesity hypoventilation
* Treatment: Being treated for Serratia pneumonia with Ceftaz for 10 days, finishing Cipro course, and PS/TC as tolerated
* Current vital signs:
	+ Temperature: 37.9°C (100.2°F)
	+ Heart rate: 90 bpm
	+ Blood pressure: 85/38 mmHg
	+ Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute
	+ SpO2: 100%
* Lab results:
	+ WBC: 15.8-16.4 K/uL
	+ Hct: 20.5-23.5%
	+ Plt: 163-259 K/uL
	+ Cr: 0.9-2.2 mg/dL
	+ Glucose: 78-176 mg/dL
	+ Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 16.9/32.4/1.5, ALT/AST: 3-24 IU/L, Alk Phos/T Bili: 105/0.1 IU/L, Differential-Neuts: 79.0%, Band: 0.0%, Lymph: 12.0%, Mono: 7.0%, Eos: 0.0%, Lactic Acid: 1.6 mmol/L, Albumin: 1.5 g/dL, LDH: 99 IU/L, Ca++: 7.5 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.5 mg/dL, PO4: 1.8 mg/dL

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is a critical condition that requires close monitoring and treatment. Prolonged respiratory failure can lead to respiratory acidosis, which can further exacerbate the patient's condition.
2. Sepsis: The patient's infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer and Serratia pneumonia increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of Afib and ESRD on HD increase the risk of cardiac arrest, which can be triggered by respiratory failure, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's ESRD on HD and history of multiple prior VAPs/HAPs increase the risk of renal failure, which can further complicate the patient's condition.
5. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's critical illness and need for mechanical ventilation increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies, which can worsen the patient's condition and prolong recovery.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of multiple prior VAPs/HAPs and current treatment with antibiotics increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea, constipation, or Clostridioides difficile infection.
7. Skin Breakdown: The patient's critical illness and immobility increase the risk of skin breakdown, which can lead to pressure ulcers, skin tears, or other skin complications.

Overall, the patient's critical condition requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with COPD, chronic respiratory failure, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD). He has a complicated hospital course, including multiple prior ventilator-associated pneumonias (VAPs) and hospital-acquired pneumonias (HAPs). He is currently being treated for Serratia pneumonia and has a tracheostomy in place. The patient is critically ill, with hypercarbic respiratory failure likely related to oversedation/obesity hypoventilation. He is being treated with Zosyn and Cipro, and his respiratory support includes continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)/pressure support ventilation (PSV) with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is likely to worsen if not managed properly. He may require further respiratory support, such as non-invasive ventilation (NIV) or invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV).
2. Sepsis: The patient's Serratia pneumonia may lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is essential to detect early signs of sepsis.
3. Ventilator-associated complications: The patient's tracheostomy and prolonged mechanical ventilation increase his risk of ventilator-associated complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and tracheal stenosis.
4. Renal dysfunction: The patient's ESRD may worsen due to his critical illness, requiring close monitoring of his renal function and potential adjustment of his dialysis regimen.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension may be related to his underlying cardiovascular disease, and close monitoring of his blood pressure and cardiac rhythm is essential to detect early signs of cardiovascular instability.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and sedation may lead to neurological complications, such as delirium, cognitive impairment, or muscle weakness.
7. Wound infection: The patient's coccygeal ulcer may become infected, which can lead to sepsis and worsen his overall condition. Close monitoring of his wound and potential surgical intervention may be necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic respiratory failure, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, and a history of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to oversedation, obesity hypoventilation, and possibly obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He is currently being treated for Serratia pneumonia and is receiving mechanical ventilation with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and pressure support ventilation (PSV). His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 90 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 85/38 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 27 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on a tracheostomy tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is a critical condition that requires close monitoring and management. He is at risk of developing further respiratory failure, which could lead to respiratory arrest and cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's Serratia pneumonia is a potential source of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial and requires close monitoring. He is at risk of developing further cardiovascular instability, which could lead to cardiac arrest and death.
4. Renal dysfunction: The patient's ESRD on hemodialysis puts him at risk of developing further renal dysfunction, which could lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and cardiovascular instability.
5. Infection: The patient's Serratia pneumonia is a potential source of further infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, which could lead to further malnutrition, weakness, and decreased immune function.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk of developing DVT due to his immobility and ESRD on hemodialysis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status, including oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, and blood gases.
2. Continue treatment for Serratia pneumonia, including antibiotics and respiratory support.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status, including blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac rhythm.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function, including blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, and electrolyte levels.
5. Consider further nutrition support, including enteral nutrition or parenteral nutrition, to improve the patient's nutritional status.
6. Consider prophylactic anticoagulation therapy to reduce the risk of DVT.
7. Continue to educate the patient and his family on his medical condition, treatment options, and potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including COPD, chronic respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, and a history of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He is currently admitted to the ICU due to hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely related to oversedation/obesity hypoventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.9°C (100.2°F)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 85/38 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 15.8-16.4 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 22.3-24.0%
* Platelet count: 163-259 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9-2.2 mg/dL
* Glucose: 78-176 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.5 g/dL
* LDH: 99 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 1.8 mg/dL

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Ciprofloxacin (finishing course)
* Ceftazidime (10 days)
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Lansoprazole (Prevacid)

The patient's imaging studies are:

* No new imaging.

The patient's microbiology results are:

* No new micro data.

The patient's assessment and plan are:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: likely related to oversedation/obesity hypoventilation
* ESRD: on hemodialysis
* Hypotension: multifactorial, stable now, follow
* Sepsis: infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, s/p diverting colostomy
* VAP: s/p tracheostomy, likely related to serratia PNA
* Sputum culture with Pseudomonas, increased sputum production, change in color to green

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening respiratory failure
* Development of septic shock
* Increased risk of VAP or other hospital-acquired infections
* Progression of ESRD
* Hypotension or hypoperfusion
* Complications related to the infected coccygeal ulcer, such as abscess formation or sepsis
* Adverse reactions to medications, such as antibiotics or anticoagulants.

   Assessment and Plan
   75 yo M with chronic respiratory failure with trach, COPD, ESRD, DM 2,
   infected stage IV coccygeal ulcer, and multiple prior VAPs/HAPs with
   complicated hospital course who now was transferred again to the [**Hospital Unit Name 44**]
   for hypercarbic respiratory failure now s/p diverting colostomy to
   allow for healing of his coccygeal ulcer.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Probable multifactorial respiratory
   failure secondary to muscular weakness, PNA and difficulty due to body
   habitus.   O/n [**1-17**] trach positional for ventilation but IP here [**1-19**]
   could not find problem with trach in multiple positions so will leave
   as is for now. Sputum from [**1-18**] now grew pseudomonas and serratia and on
   [**9-25**] no longer serratia but with providencia and pseudomonas.   We are
   currently treating this as the patient has low grade fever and
   leukocytosis.  WBC flat.
   - Continue [**4-20**]
   - Ceftazidime for 10D course started [**2-2**].
   - Atrovent nebs and prn albuterol nebs
   # ESRD: More hypotensive and seems slightly less responsive this
   morning than previously.  Will discuss with nephrology re: plausible or
   indicated to continue HD when consistently required to give back
   volume.  Possible this is no longer indicated.
   -d/w feasibility of continued dialysis with nephrology
   -no emergent HD needs
   -no indication for CVVH as not a transitional theory to anything
   # Hypotension:  Most likely multifactorial with chronic wound
   infection, retracting ostomy and other issues.  Weaned off Levo since
   [**1-18**]. TSH elevated and free T4 low [**1-18**] but likely sick thyroid.
   Cortisol checked and normal.
   -continue midodrine, fludracortisone stopped after nephrology indicated
   cannot work w/ no renal function
   -monitor BPs, mentation
   -consider gentle boluses for hypotension prn
   # S/P Diverting Colostomy: Patient had diverting colostomy on [**1-6**].
   Bridge removed during 1st week of [**Month (only) 1088**] and some necrosis around
   site.  Surgery aware and think appearance is not encouraging but few
   options for management.  Family aware there are no further surgical
   options and ostomy may retract into abdomen leading to catastrophic
   stool contamination.
   -continue ostomy care
   -f/u surgery reccs
   # Stage IV coccygeal ulcer: s/p  diverting colostomy [**1-6**]. Seems to be
   improving. Plastics debrided extensively [**1-20**] and placed wound vac.
   Debrided again and wound vac replaced [**1-29**].
   - Cont current wound care
   - Pain not ideally controlled with 100 mcg fentanyl patch , lidocaine
   patches and morphine PRN
   # Anemia: Hct back to 23 today.  Will keep transfusion goal Hct >21%
   # Hyperglycemia: Patient persistently hyperglycemic with BG
s in
   200
s-300
s.  Will increase glargine from 10-15 units QAM.
   # Depression: The patient has been showing decreased interest and signs
   of depression given his current medical situation
   - Cont citalopram 30 mg daily
   - Social work following
   # CAD: TTE [**3-24**] (EF 50% to 55%) with dilated LV cavity. No signs of
   active cardiac ischemia on labs or EKG. Elevated troponin in setting of
   renal failure, and stable from prior checks.
   -Continue statin, off BB until BPs tolerate.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: No active issues.  INR subtherapeutic but
   holding coumadin  for the moment given multiple other medications,
   potential for more procedures, and generally poor prognosis.
   # Osteomyelitis:  No active issues
          -finished meropenem ([**1-11**] was the completion of 6 week course).
   # R BKA/PVD
   - Continue current wound care
   # Plasma Cell Dyscrasia: Known IgA kappa on electrophoresis. Bone
   Marrow with 5-10% plasma cells. ?MGUS. Known retroperitoneal mass s/p
   non-diagnostic FNA and needle core biopsy indicating lymphoid tissue
   with quiescent germinal centers.
   #Prophylaxis: PPI, heparin SC
   #Code: Full for moment
   #Ethics: Nursing and Housestaff with major concerns about futility and
   benefit of further procedures and intentions in this patient given poor
   functional status and fact that further pressors worsen wound
   dehiscence and breakdown, may consider pursuing hospital policy
   regarding futile care and CPR not indicated (will discuss w/ ethics and
   attending)
